title: Erdős Problem #7: Odd Covering Systems
description: Is there a covering system all of whose moduli are odd? Also known as the Erdős-Selfridge Conjecture. OPEN with significant partial results.

overview.historicalContext: This problem asks whether covering systems can avoid even moduli. A covering system is a finite collection of congruence classes that cover all integers. Erdős and Selfridge conjectured that at least one modulus must be even. Related to Problem #2 which bounded the minimum modulus.
overview.problemStatement: Is there a covering system all of whose moduli are odd? Equivalently, must every covering system have at least one even modulus?
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines covering systems via CongruenceClass and CoveringSystem structures, with toSet mapping classes to sets of integers via modular arithmetic. The Erdős-Selfridge conjecture is stated in two equivalent forms. Key partial results are axiomatized: Hough-Nielsen (divisibility by 2 or 3), Balister et al. (no odd squarefree coverings), and LCM constraints.
keyInsights: Conjecture: NO odd covering system exists
Hough-Nielsen (2019): At least one modulus must be divisible by 2 or 3
Balister et al. (2022): No covering exists with all moduli odd AND squarefree
LCM constraint: If an odd covering exists, its LCM must be divisible by 9 or 15
Selfridge offered $2000 for an explicit construction (separate from Erdős's $25)

conclusion.summary: We formalize Erdős Problem #7 (Erdős-Selfridge Conjecture), an OPEN problem asking whether there exists a covering system with all moduli odd. The conjecture predicts NO such system exists. Significant partial results are formalized: Hough-Nielsen (2019) proved some modulus must be divisible by 2 or 3, and Balister et al. (2022) ruled out odd squarefree coverings.
conclusion.implications: This problem constrains the structure of covering systems. If proven, it would show that the prime 2 plays a special role in coverings. The partial results already severely limit what an odd covering could look like: it must have non-squarefree moduli, the LCM must be divisible by 9 or 15, and some modulus must be divisible by 3.
openQuestions: Does an odd covering system exist? (The main question)
If an odd covering exists, what is its minimum number of classes?
What is the structure of the smallest odd covering (if any)?
Can computational searches help resolve this problem?
